Award.AwardTitle: Representations of affine Kac-Moody algebras and representations of Groups over a 2-dimensional local field
Award.AbstractNarration:
Let G be a complex semi-simple group, and let g be its Lie algebra.
Our main object of study is the Kac-Moody extension g' of the loop
algebra g((t)); more specifically, the category of representations of
g' at the critical level, denoted g'_(crit)-mod. Our goal is to develop a
localization theory for this category, i.e., to relate it to other categories
that are constructed locally out of spaces, endowed with an action
of the loop group G((t)), such as the affine Grassmannian. Ultimately,
we believe that the structure of g'_(crit)-mod is governed by a pattern
of local Langlands correspondence, i.e., its extrinsic structure can be
described solely in terms of the space of local systems on the formal
punctured disc with respect to the Langlands dual group.
The second (and, so far, unrelated) part of the project is the development
of representation theory for groups associated to G and 2-dimensional local
fields.

The object of study of the current project is representation theory.
Starting from the 1930's it was realized that there is fairly small list
of types of possible fundamental symmetries that occur in Nature.
These types are called "root data", and the corresponding concrete
mathematical objects are called semi-simple groups. In order to have
a representation theory one has to pick one of those semi-simple
groups and couple it with a data of algebraic or analytic nature, such
as what is known in mathematics as a "field" or "ring", e.g., real or
complex numbers. Having a representation theory, the objects that
one deals with look fairly complicated, and most of the questions that
one can ask are not amenable to complete answers. However, we
hope to find a point of view on representations, which, on the one
hand, would answer some deep questions about their structure, and,
on the other hand, will ultimately reduce to questions about the
initial data, i.e., the root system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project comprised several directions:

 

A. Representation theory of affine algebras at the critical level.

The goal of the project was to give an explicit geometric description of the category of representations, which are Iwahori-integrable and on which the action of the center is given by nilpotent opers. Such description was finally proved inthe paper "D-modules on the affine flag variety and representations of affine Kac-Moody algebras",  Representation Theory 13 (2009), 470-680.

In process of doing to, we have developed localization theory for modules at the critical level.

At the conceptual level, thinking about representations of the affine Kac-Moody algebra at the critical level has led us to the formalism of 2-categorical local geometric Langlands correspondence.

 

B. Quantum geometric Langlands correspondence.

This project is a far-reaching program that is intended to restore symmetry between the group G and its Langlands dual in both the local and global aspects of the theory. The work on this project requires developing the notion of 1-representation of an algebraic group, which in turn requires developing a lot of foundations in derived algebraic geometry.

The initial ingredient is a quantum version of the geometric Satake equivalence established in  "Twisted Whittaker model and factorizable sheaves", Selecta Math. (N.S.) 13 (2008), no. 4, 617-659.

 

C. Categorical global Langlands correspondence.

The hope of the categorical global Langlands correspondence was to establish an equivalence
between the (derived) category D-mod}(Bun(G)) and the (derived) category D-mod(LocSys(G^)). However, it has been known for a while that the above equivalence is wrong as stated. However, recently,  we were able to find an appropriate modification of the right-hand side, so that the resulting conjecture survives the available tests.

I have undertaken the project of writing down the various ingredients of this theory as a series of informal notes available at

http://www.math.harvard.edu/~gaitsgde/GL/

 

D. Other projects:

"Relation between two geometrically defined bases in representations of GL(n)" (with A. Braverman and M. Vybornov), in: Qauntum Groups, 103-113, Contemp. Math 433, AMS (2007).

"Deformations of local systems and Eisenstein series" (with A. Braverman),
Geom. Funct. Anal. 17 (2008), no 6, 1788-1850.

"On de Jong's conjecture", Israel J. of Math. 157 (2007), 155-191.

"Spherical varieties and Langlands duality" (with D. Nadler), Moscow Math. J. 10 (2010), no 1, 65-137.

"A corollary of the b-function lemma" (with A. Beilinson), arXiv.math: 0810.1504, to appear in Selecta Mathematica.

"Chiral Koszul duality" (with J. Francis), arXiv.math: 1103.5803, to appear in Selecta Mathematica.
